user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_nc:
```c
static enum MHD_GetRqNCResult
get_rq_nc (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params,
           uint32_t *nc)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const nc_param =
    &params->nc;
  char unq[16];
  const char *val;
  size_t val_len;
  size_t res;
  uint64_t nc_val;

  if (NULL == nc_param->value.str)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_NONE;

  if (0 == nc_param->value.len)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;

  if (! nc_param->quoted)
  {
    val = nc_param->value.str;
    val_len = nc_param->value.len;
  }
  else
  {
    /* Actually no backslashes must be used in 'nc' */
    if (sizeof(unq) < params->nc.value.len)
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LONG;
    val_len = MHD_str_unquote (nc_param->value.str, nc_param->value.len, unq);
    if (0 == val_len)
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
    val = unq;
  }

  res = MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (val, val_len, &nc_val);
  if (0 == res)
  {
    const char f = val[0];
    if ( (('9' >= f) && ('0' <= f)) ||
         (('F' >= f) && ('A' <= f)) ||
         (('a' <= f) && ('f' >= f)) )
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LARGE;
    else
      return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
  }
  if (val_len != res)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_BROKEN;
  if (UINT32_MAX < nc_val)
    return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_TOO_LARGE;
  *nc = (uint32_t) nc_val;
  return MHD_GET_RQ_NC_VALID;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are invariant. All conditional expressions depend on runtime data or function results:

- if (NULL == nc_param->value.str) — tests a pointer value provided at runtime.
- if (0 == nc_param->value.len) — tests a runtime length field.
- if (! nc_param->quoted) — tests a runtime flag.
- if (sizeof(unq) < params->nc.value.len) — sizeof(unq) is constant but compared to params->nc.value.len (runtime), so the overall expression is not invariant.
- if (0 == val_len) — val_len is set from MHD_str_unquote (runtime function result).
- if (0 == res) — res is set from MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (runtime function result).
- The character-range tests using f (('9' >= f) && ('0' <= f)) || ... — depend on f = val[0], which is runtime data.
- if (val_len != res) — both are runtime-derived values.
- if (UINT32_MAX < nc_val) — compares a runtime-parsed nc_val to the constant.

There are no loops or do-while constructs with constant controlling expressions (no invariant controlling expressions used to create infinite loops), and no controlling expressions that are simple compile-time constants. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
